Data:', data); }); chart(); }).catch(error => { console.log('error', error); }) Leetcode activities const lcUrl = 'https://leetcode.com/api/user_submission_calendar/kjs927/'; axios.get(`${cors}${lcUrl}`, { crossDomain: true }).then(res => { var dataList = new Array(); // *********************************** // ** success => process data ** // *********************************** var chartData = res.data; chartData = chartData.toString(); chartData = chartData.replace('{', ''); chartData = chartData.replace('}', ''); chartData = chartData.replace(/(?:\\[rn]|[\r\n]+)+/g, ""); //console.log(data); chartData = chartData.split(','); for (var i = 0; i < chartData.length; i++) { var d = chartData[i].split(':'); var s = {"date": new Date(parseInt(d[0].replace(/[^0-9]/g, ''))*1000), "count": parseInt(d[1])}; dataList.push(s); } // *********************************** // ** render chart ** // *********************************** var yearago = new Date(new Date().setFullYear(new Date().getFullYear() - 1)); yearago.setMonth(yearago.getMonth()); var chart = calendarHeatmap() .data(dataList) .selector('#leetcode-cal-heatmap') .startDate(yearago) .colorRange(['#dae289', '#3b6427']) .tooltipEnabled(true) .legendEnabled(true) .onClick(function (data) { console.log('onClick callback. Data:', data); }); chart(); }).catch(error => { console.log('error', error); }) Other Special thanks to Hexo,  Icarus for blog templates, iMaeGoo for Night Mode, 辣椒の酱  to customize blog templates, Rob–W,  DKirwan for Heatmap Calendar, 瑪利歐的部落格 for blog deployment.

posts.title: Access Localhost from Anywhere with Ngrok
posts.text: Public URLs for exposing your local web server. https://ngrok.com/download Example:(1). Usage on Windows (my host machine). ngrok help12345678910111213141516171819202122232425262728EXAMPLES: ngrok http 80 # secure public URL for port 80 web server ngrok http -subdomain=baz 8080 # port 8080 available at baz.ngrok.io ngrok http foo.dev:80 # tunnel to host:port instead of localhost ngrok http https://localhost # expose a local https server ngrok tcp 22 # tunnel arbitrary TCP traffic to port 22 ngrok tls -hostname=foo.com 443 # TLS traffic for foo.com to port 443 ngrok start foo bar baz # start tunnels from the configuration fileVERSION: 2.3.35AUTHOR: inconshreveable - <alan@ngrok.com>COMMANDS: authtoken save authtoken to configuration file credits prints author and licensing information http start an HTTP tunnel start start tunnels by name from the configuration file tcp start a TCP tunnel tls start a TLS tunnel update update ngrok to the latest version version print the version string help Shows a list of commands or help for one commandngrok is a command line application, try typing 'ngrok.exe http 80'at this terminal prompt to expose port 80. (2). To expose web server with a HTTP tunnel on port 23000 on Windows. ngrok http 23000 (3). We can surf the web from anywhere now. Referencengrok Official Website

(6). sudo systemctl enable tomcat9(7). sudo systemctl restart tomcat9(8). done! Test and deploy an application(1) Freestyle project create it get git url pull test set up build settings build test install deploy plugin configure deployment settings add credential for tomcat test deploy done! (2). Maven project install Maven Integration create maven project set up build settings configure deployment settings test it error caused by jenkins jdk add correct jdk configure project jdk build it again done! Referencehttps://linuxconfig.org/ubuntu-20-04-tomcat-installation

posts.title: Building CI/CD Pipelines with IDEA, Gitlab, Jenkins and Kubernetes - Topic 2.3 - Jenkins (Pull, Build and Deploy)
posts.text: Pipeline Project tutorial Hello, Declarative Pipeline Script(1). select New Item from dashboard (2). select Pipeline project and OK (3). find Pipeline on project configuration, select Hello World (4). Hello World script will display (5). customize, apply and save (6). build test done! Hello, Scripted Pipeline Script(1). select New Item from dashboard (2). select Pipeline project and OK (3). find Pipeline on project configuration, select Scripted Pipeline (4). Scripted Pipeline script will display customize (5). build test, done! Start a pipeline project(1). back to project (2). add pull script initialize, and select Pipeline Syntax select steps -> checkout fill Git form Generate Pipeline Script and copy generated string paste it to Pull stage on Pipeline script configuration pull test done! (3). add build script generate build script from Pipeline Syntax paste it to Build stage on Pipeline script configuration, apply and save build test done! (4). add deploy script back to project generate script from Pipeline Syntax paste it to Deploy stage on Pipeline script configuration, apply and save deploy test done! Start a pipeline project from SCM (for version control)(1). add Jenkinsfile on root directory (2). copy Pipeline script configuration (3). paste it on Jenkinsfile (4). commit (5). push (6). change Pipeline->Definition to Pipeline script from SCM (7). fill Git form (8). done!

Manage Jenkins -> Manage Plugins (3). select “Available” tab and search “Role-based Authorization Strategy” (4). mark it and click “Download now and install after restart” (5). login (6). Manage Jenkins -> Configure Global Security (7). change “Authorization Strategy” to “Role-Base Strategy” and save (8). go back to “Manage Jenkins” (9). find “Manage and Assign Roles” (10). select “Manage Roles” (11). add base role (12). add item roles (for projects) (13). apply and save (14). go back to “Manage Jenkins” (15). select “Manage Users” (16). create test users (charlie and david) (17). login with charlieoops (18). login with admin bob (19). assign role to charlie, Manage Jenkins->”Manage and Assign Roles” (20). login with charlie again (OK) (21). login with bob again, assign roles to charlie and david (22). create projects for testing roles (23). charlie’s view (24). david’s view Add credentials2.1 by username and password (1). Manage Jenkins->Manage Credentials (2). click “global” (3). add credential (4). back to dashboard (5). select a project (6). fill git form (7). save, back to project and “Build Now” (8). click “Build History” item (9). check “Console Output”, done! 2.2 by ssh (1). ssh-keygen -t rsassh-keygen -t rsa123456789101112131415161718192021Generating public/private rsa key pair.Enter file in which to save the key (/home/webdev/.ssh/id_rsa):Enter passphrase (empty for no passphrase):Enter same passphrase again:Your identification has been saved in /home/webdev/.ssh/id_rsaYour public key has been saved in /home/webdev/.ssh/id_rsa.pubThe key fingerprint is:SHA256:xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxThe key's randomart image is:+---[RSA 3072]----+| xxxxxxxxxx || xxxxxxxxxx || xxxxxxxxx || xxxxxxxxxx || xxxxxxxxxx|| xxxxxxxxx|| xxxxxxxx|| .o.o o*.=|| xxxxxxxxx|+----[SHA256]-----+ (2). cd /home/webdev/.ssh/ && llcd /home/webdev/.ssh/ && ll123456total 16drwx------ 2 webdev webdev 4096 Jul 15 17:11 ./drwxr-xr-x 19 webdev webdev 4096 Jul 15 15:23 ../-rw------- 1 webdev webdev 2610 Jul 15 17:11 id_rsa-rw-r--r-- 1 webdev webdev 578 Jul 15 17:11 id_rsa.pub id_rsa and id_rsa.pub are important! (3). add ssh key on Gitlab login Gitlab add id_rsa.pub content to settings -> SSH Keys (4). add ssh key on Jenkins enter “Manage Credentials” add ssh credential by the id_rsa content (5). back to dashboard (6). “New Item” (7). get ssh url from Gitlab project (8). fill git form on Jenkins, apply and save (9). “Build Now” (10). check the result, done! Referencehttps://openjdk.java.net/install/https://www.jenkins.io/doc/book/installing/#debianubuntu

posts.title: Building a Spring Boot Application Using Intellij IDEA
posts.text: “Spring makes programming Java quicker, easier, and safer for everybody. Spring’s focus on speed, simplicity, and productivity has made it the world’s most popular Java framework.” - spring.io Install IntelliJ IDEA Start IntelliJ IDEA and Create New Project Select Spring Initializr -> Project SDKand Next. Project Settings (Optional)and Next. Select Dependencies (Enable Web -> Spring Web Here)and Next. Select Project Location Setup Maven (a build automation tool used primarily for Java projects)(1). File -> Settings(2). Build, Execution and Deployment -> Build Tools -> Maven(3). Download Apache Maven (https://maven.apache.org/) and Create a Folder for Maven Repository(4). Setup Apache Maven folder -> conf folder -> settings.xml(5). Fill Maven home directory, User settings file and Local repository in Intellij IDEA settings.Apply and OK(6). We Got Some Error Information from Default Maven Settings Here(7). Click Reload All Maven Projects on Top-Right Corner, and Wait for Maven Import Completion(8). Errors were resolved Create a Simple Web ApplicationCreate a Simple Web Application1234567891011121314package com.example.springboot;import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RestController;import org.springframework.web.bind.annotation.RequestMapping;@RestControllerpublic class HelloController { @RequestMapping("/") public String index() { return "Greetings from Spring Boot!"; }} Click Run DemoApplication Button on Top-Right Corner (Shift + F10) Done! ReferenceIntelliJ IDEA Official WebsiteSpring Official WebsiteApache Maven Official Website

posts.title: What's the Difference Between CI and CD (and the Other CD)?
posts.text: Abstract from RedHat [What is CI/CD?] Continuous integration (CI) helps developers merge their code changes back to a shared branch, or “trunk,” more frequently—sometimes even daily. If automated testing discovers a conflict between new and existing code, CI makes it easier to fix those bugs quickly and often. Continuous delivery (CD), the goal of continuous delivery is to have a codebase that is always ready for deployment to a production environment. Continuous deployment (CD), as an extension of continuous delivery, continuous deployment means that a developer’s change to a cloud application could go live within minutes of writing it (assuming it passes automated testing). This makes it much easier to continuously receive and incorporate user feedback.   Relationship Diagram Red Hat, Inc.Source: https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/devops/what-is-ci-cd Code MazeSource: https://www.codeproject.com/articles/1078439/what-is-continuous-integration-and-why-do-you-need Referencehttps://www.redhat.com/en/topics/devops/what-is-ci-cdhttp://devopstechie.com/continuous-integration-vs-continuous-delivery-vs-continuous-deployment/
